update.description:
Given the heavy load of tests in the compilation it might be convenient to disable them by default and have to enable them explicitly.

Be sure that we merge the [corresponding pull request in release-tools](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/319/enable-test-suite-compilation-explicitly/diff) before so we don't end up without tests.
update.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

content.raw: Thanks for the feedback. I've created [a different PR](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2499/disable-tests-compilation-by-default-new/diff) implementing the 'make tests' idea. I think that it is a pretty intrusive change to be included in the gazebo7 series (specially thinking in downstream maintainers) so I targeted it to gazebo8. My personal impression is that would be better to decline this PR so we don't end up with different changes go at the same time to two active branches (generating confusion in gazebo developers) but I can be convinced of merging both if you think otherwise.
content.html: Thanks for the feedback. I've created a different PR implementing the 'make tests' idea. I think that it is a pretty intrusive change to be included in the gazebo7 series (specially thinking in downstream maintainers) so I targeted it to gazebo8. My personal impression is that would be better to decline this PR so we don't end up with different changes go at the same time to two active branches (generating confusion in gazebo developers) but I can be convinced of merging both if you think otherwise.

pull_request.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

pullrequest.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

content.raw:
We currently support the build of individual tests so this change will remove the `ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION` variable (I'm for it if possible) at the cost of not being able to separate the compilation and run target in make (`make tests` will do both). I don't think that is currently critical not to have the run and compilation of tests separately but I see some use cases where it could be in a CI environment (track time spent in compilation vs time spent in running tests, have different machines for compilation and execution of tests, ...).

Update: just notice the value of having all the tests target generated without the need of running cmake again. This is useful.
content.html:
We currently support the build of individual tests so this change will remove the ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION variable (I'm for it if possible) at the cost of not being able to separate the compilation and run target in make (make tests will do both). I don't think that is currently critical not to have the run and compilation of tests separately but I see some use cases where it could be in a CI environment (track time spent in compilation vs time spent in running tests, have different machines for compilation and execution of tests, ...).

Update: just notice the value of having all the tests target generated without the need of running cmake again. This is useful.

pull_request.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

pullrequest.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

content.raw: I thought `make tests` would compile the tests, but not run them? So `make test` would still be required to run them?
content.html: I thought make tests would compile the tests, but not run them? So make test would still be required to run them?

pull_request.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

pullrequest.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

content.raw:
Indeed, I'm working on a project using gazebo from source right now and recompiling the tests was making my compile take more than 3-4x longer so I ended up disabling the builds in the CMake to save time. As a new to compiling from source user I spent a lot of time building the tests until I noticed that 75% of the time was building tests that I am not using. 

I'd recommend not building all the tests by default as it will make life better for new users who don't know better. And the gazebo developers who need them can turn them on easily. +1 for @jlee02 's suggestion to use custom targets, though it might be worth leaving the CMake option to disable them entirely, but leave that turned on.
content.html:
Indeed, I'm working on a project using gazebo from source right now and recompiling the tests was making my compile take more than 3-4x longer so I ended up disabling the builds in the CMake to save time. As a new to compiling from source user I spent a lot of time building the tests until I noticed that 75% of the time was building tests that I am not using.

I'd recommend not building all the tests by default as it will make life better for new users who don't know better. And the gazebo developers who need them can turn them on easily. +1 for @jlee02 's suggestion to use custom targets, though it might be worth leaving the CMake option to disable them entirely, but leave that turned on.

pull_request.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

pullrequest.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

content.raw:
One alternative would be using CMake custom target for the tests. The advantage of using the custom target is that we don't need to rerun cmake for building gazebo with and without tests.

How to:

* remove `ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION`
* add the test directory with option `EXCLUDE_FROM_ALL` as `add_subdirectory(tests EXCLUDE_FROM_ALL)`
* add custom target as `add_custom_target(tests DEPENDS ${LIST_OF_TESTS})`

Once you've done this you could build:

* the default targets: `make` or `make all`
* individual test target: `make test_name_001`
* all the tests: `make tests`
content.html:
One alternative would be using CMake custom target for the tests. The advantage of using the custom target is that we don't need to rerun cmake for building gazebo with and without tests.

How to:

  • remove ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION
  • add the test directory with option EXCLUDE_FROM_ALL as add_subdirectory(tests EXCLUDE_FROM_ALL)
  • add custom target as add_custom_target(tests DEPENDS ${LIST_OF_TESTS})

Once you've done this you could build:

  • the default targets: make or make all
  • individual test target: make test_name_001
  • all the tests: make tests
